In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A key requirement for the achievement of inclusive growth is the generation of decent 
employment opportunities for broad segments of the population. Decent jobs provide productive 
and satisfying work situations, livable wages, social security and protection, and a measure of 
job stability. These elements allow women and men to share in the fruits of national economic 
growth and to provide for the health, nutrition, and education of their children. Ensuring access 
to  employment  opportunities  is  a  key  element  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB’s) 
inclusive growth framework and supports Strategy 2020.1 
 
2.  Providing  the  right  environment  for  decent  employment  is  a  chief  challenge  and 
preoccupation of governments in the region. Policies at a number of levels will impact on 
employment  outcomes.  Macroeconomic  policy  sets  the  broad  framework  for  investment, 
production, and thus job creation. At the same time, labor market policies can facilitate hiring by 
reducing search costs or inhibit hiring by increasing the costs of engaging workers. Finally, 
quality education and skills training is critical to ensuring that individuals gain skills that meet the 
needs of employers.    
 
3.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  study  the  functioning  of  labor  markets,  including 
market failures and government attempts to overcome those failures, in Cambodia, Viet Nam, 
and two other developing member countries (DMCs).2 The details of the TA, including the 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation, cost, and other aspects will be presented to each 
country’s government and clearance will be secured before TA implementation is initiated.3 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES     
4.  The demand-side issues of generating decent employment opportunities are rooted in 
the larger evolution of the economy, notably its structural transformation, the level of investment, 
and the employment intensity of that investment. A country’s specific product mix and use of 
technology (capital intensity) will further shape the nature of job creation. While investment is 
fundamental to job creation, it is only one of the factors that determine employment outcomes. 
The nature of labor market policies, laws, regulations, and institutions (PLRIs) and the education 
and skills mix of the population are also significant factors.  
 
5.  PLRIs that govern the labor market may inhibit the hiring of prospective workers into 
decent jobs in the formal sector. A fundamental asymmetry exists between jobseekers who are 
looking for the right job, and employers who are seeking to fill vacancies with candidates that 
possess the right mix of skills, attitudes, and competencies. The public employment service is 
designed to overcome this asymmetry by providing a matching function but often provides that 
function inadequately. In many countries, the job matching role is shifting to electronic portals, 
but they tend only to service more wealthy segments that are computer literate and have access

to hardware and the internet.4 A national qualifications framework can also assist by providing 
an agreed set of standards against which employers can make hiring decisions.5   
 
6.  Aside from the asymmetry problem, other labor market PLRIs can inhibit hiring. These 
regulations  can  make  it  costly  to  hire  workers  formally  (owing  to  wage  and  non-wage 
requirements), in particular because they make it difficult for employers to alter their workforce 
as required by changing business conditions. Chief among these barriers are restrictions on 
retrenching workers, limits on the ability to alter the scope or hours of a worker’s work, the cost 
of  retrenchment  in  terms  of  severance  and  related  payments,  and  other  regulations  on 
entitlements. For example, in Viet Nam an employer must pay 43 weeks of salary to a laid-off 
worker who has been employed for 10 years or more. If the worker has been employed for 
20 years or more, the payout is 83 weeks (about 1.5 years of salary). In Cambodia, employer 
obligations are less onerous—21 weeks of pay for 10 years of service and 26 weeks of pay for 
20 years of service.6 Some countries are moving to a more balanced system of “flexicurity” that 
combines flexibility for employers with state-supported security (social protection) for workers. 
Such newer systems rely less on older systems of rigid retrenchment provisions and onerous 
employer-based severance obligations.7     
 
7.  To achieve positive employment outcomes, a system of general as well as technical 
vocational  education  and  training  is  needed  that  is  highly  developed  at  three  key  stages. 
Stage 1 is access to education and skills training opportunities; stage 2 is the provision of high 
quality and market-relevant education and skills to students, trainees, and workers; and stage 3 
is the transition of educated and skilled people into employment (or in the case of in-service 
upgrading, their continued employment). Stages 2 and 3 are highly interrelated; without relevant 
skills, it is difficult to place trainees and graduates in decent work situations. Women, youth, 
ethnic minorities, lower caste members, remote residents, people living with disabilities, and the 
poor and lower-middle class face particular challenges in accessing decent education and 
training and, by extension, employment opportunities. 
 
8.  To ensure that jobseekers have the attributes demanded by employers, a sound labor 
market information system is needed. Such a system allows information about the needs of 
employers to be communicated back to young people embarking on education and to education 
institutes. Viet Nam, with assistance from the International Labour Organization (ILO), has 
recently set up a labor market information system. Education and training curricula need to 
synchronize with the needs of the job market for the effective matching of the supply of skilled 
workers  with  the  demand  by  enterprises.8 Without  such  synchronization,  people  will  have 
difficulty finding work and economies will have difficulty producing quality goods and services 
efficiently. This is important for all countries and may be especially critical for those seeking to 
avoid the middle-income trap. Furthermore, not only might graduates and existing workers 
possess the wrong skills, but a large portion of the labor force, including new entrants, may be 
unskilled.

9.  Evidence from enterprise surveys highlights these problems. An “inadequately educated 
workforce” is listed as the 4th most important business constraint in Viet Nam and the 8th most 
important in Cambodia. Furthermore, the percentage of production workers in enterprises that 
are considered “unskilled” remains relatively high in many Asian countries—26% in Cambodia 
and 21% in Viet Nam.9  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be the use of improved labor market analysis for better economic policy 
and sector planning decisions by four DMCs and ADB. The outcome will be improved analysis 
and  understanding  of  labor  markets  that  feed  into  ADB’s  country  diagnostic  studies,  the 
government’s medium-term planning, and ADB’s operations. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.   The TA will assess the nature of the labor market and labor market policies in four DMCs. 
The methodology will be based on, but also expand and develop, the approach used in ADB’s 
country  diagnostic  studies  (CDSs).  The  CDS  approach  combines  the  well-known  growth 
diagnostics framework developed by Hausmann, Rodrik, and Velasco10 with the diagnostic 
framework for inclusiveness that has been added by ADB to ensure sufficient focus on poverty, 
inequality, employment, and other aspects of socioeconomic inclusion.11 The TA will develop 
the labor market aspects of the CDS approach and then apply it in the four DMCs.   
 
12.  Considerable analysis of the labor market and the education and training sector has 
been undertaken by various organizations in the two countries specified under this TA. ADB and 
other agencies, such as the ILO, have recently completed or have ongoing projects in the areas 
of education, including technical vocational education and training, and labor market information. 
Furthermore, two recently approved TA projects in the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department focus on various aspects of green jobs, gender, skills, and labor markets.12 The TA 
will build on and complement the research, analysis, and activities that have been undertaken to 
date, and generate synergies with the two recently approved TA projects.   
 
13.  A  specific  focus  of  the  TA  will  be  on  the  flow  of  information  between  and  among 
employers, jobseekers, youth entering post-basic education, labor market policy planners in 
government,  and  the  education  system,  including  education  and  training  institutes.  The 
information flows will be mapped and key stakeholders surveyed to determine bottlenecks that 
inhibit private and public planning for employment and skills. In conducting the analysis, the 
research will take into account structural change, patterns of investment that shape employment 
demand, the flow of individuals between rural and urban areas, and the nature of formal versus

informal employment. As appropriate, the analysis may draw on data from existing household 
and labor market surveys conducted by national statistics offices or other agencies, where such 
data is relevant and timely. In conducting the analysis and data gathering, distinctions will be 
made based on gender and socioeconomic status (poor and non-poor, etc.) and other relevant 
criteria where possible and as appropriate to the analysis.    
 
14.    The TA will have two main components: (i) in-depth country assessments, as outlined 
above;  and  (ii)  broad  dissemination  of  the  key  findings  and  recommendations,  principally 
through discussion at a national forum with policy makers and other stakeholders. The criteria 
for country selection under the TA include: the labor market being at a critical stage in the 
process  of  industrialization  and  economic  transformation;  the  opportunity  to  inform  the 
governments’  medium-term  development  planning  in  these  areas;  and,  the  opportunity  to 
provide inputs to the country partnership strategy and country diagnostic study.13  Such phased 
approach will allow insights from the two initial studies under this TA to improve the detailed 
design and scope of the other two studies that will be carried out under this TA in 2013, 
ensuring that learning takes place over the course of the TA. 
 
15.    Expanding access to good employment opportunities is fundamental to ensuring that the 
benefits of growth in Asia are widely distributed among the population, including women, youth, 
the poor and lower-middle class, and other disadvantaged groups. The TA strongly supports 
inclusive growth, which is one of the three pillars of ADB’s Strategy 2020. Inclusive growth is a 
key component of the Economics and Research Department Priorities for 2010–2012,14 and its 
Strategic Initiatives for 2012–2014 (draft), which emphasizes the importance of “operations 
support through rigorous research,” which this TA will seek to achieve through its targeting of 
the country partnership strategy process. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000 equivalent and will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($400,000 from TASF-IV and $400,000 from TASF-
other sources). The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 29 months from December 2011 to April 2014.15 ADB 
will be the executing agency and the Economic Analysis and Operations Support Division of 
ERD will lead TA implementation and administration. ADB will provide funding and staff time for 
the implementation, management, and successful completion of the TA. While management will 
be based in ERD, which is a knowledge department, collaboration with regional department(s) 
and resident mission(s) will ensure that cross-fertilization between departments and that the 
results of the TA will benefit ADB’s operations. In addition, collaboration is envisioned with the 
Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD), given the two related TA projects

Practice.  While  a  formal  interdepartmental  working  group  specifically  for  this  TA  is  not 
envisioned, the progress and results of this TA will be shared in forums that include the other 
two, including any working group that might be established to generate synergies among the

18.  Participation  of  government  ministries  (finance,  education,  and  labor)  and  agencies 
along  with  employers’  and  workers’  organizations  in  consultations,  preparation  of  country 
assessments, and finalization and dissemination workshops are anticipated. ADB will interact 
with other international agencies in country, such as the World Bank and the ILO, to share 
findings  and  participate  in  events.  Government  and  international  agencies  will  also  be 
approached for data. 
 
19.  The  services  of  a  firm  or  firms,  based  on  quality-  and  cost-based  selection,  or, 
alternatively,  individual  international  and  national  consultants,  with  expertise  in  education, 
training, labor markets, editing, and graphics, will be recruited and engaged in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The activity 
will  require  23  person-months  of  international  and  at  least  34  person-months  of  national 
consulting input. The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. Disbursements 
will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time.)   
        
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving Employment Outcomes, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Specialists are required to implement the Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical 
assistance (TA) on Improving Employment Outcomes. Expertise is needed to conduct, produce, 
and disseminate country assessments of the labor market. Expertise will be engaged through a 
firm (or firms) and/or individual consultants.     
 
B.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Senior labor market economist or employment specialist (14 person-months). The 
consultant will have extensive knowledge and experience related to employment and labor 
markets,  specifically  with  respect  to  Asia.  The  consultant  will  have  a  proven  track  record 
providing assistance and working jointly with a project team leader in directing, researching, and 
managing large research projects with multiple country consultants and generating high quality 
outputs. The consultant should be able to distill, synthesize, and perform in-depth analysis of 
employment constraints impact employment generation. The consultant will be able to develop 
relevant and realistic policy recommendations and be able to present them to key stakeholders 
and policymakers in a coherent manner.   
 
3.  The main responsibilities of the consultant will be the following:    
(i)  review and synthesize the relevant literature in the field and ensure that the TA is 
at the cutting edge of thinking about employment generation in Asia; 
(ii)  provide the team leader with expert guidance and advice for the smooth and 
successful implementation of the TA; 
(iii)  liaise  with, and  provide  advice  and  guidance  to, country-level  consultants in 
conducting their country assessments, and later review and comment on those 
assessments; 
(iv)  help organize and participate in the various training sessions, consultations, and 
workshops of the TA, including those where country assessments are presented; 
(v)  co-author final reports and publications of the TA; and 
(vi)  perform  other  tasks  that  may  be  required  to  ensure  successful  and  timely 
completion of the TA.  
 
4.  Senior education and skills specialist (5 person-months). The consultant will have 
extensive knowledge and experience related to education and skills training, specifically with 
respect  to  Asia.  The  consultant  will  have  a  proven  track  record  providing  assistance  and 
working  in  directing,  researching,  and  managing  large  research  projects  with  country 
consultants  and  generating  high  quality  outputs.  The  consultant  should  be  able  to  distill, 
synthesize,  and  perform  in-depth  analysis  of  education  and  skills  constraints  that  affect 
employment.  The  consultant  will  be  able  to  develop  relevant  and  realistic  policy 
recommendations and be able to present them to key stakeholders and policy makers in a 
coherent manner.   
 
5.  The main responsibilities of the consultant will be the following:    
(i)  review and synthesize the relevant literature in the field and ensure that the TA is 
at the cutting edge of thinking about education and skills training in Asia; 
(ii)  provide  expert  guidance  and  advice  for  the  smooth  and  successful 
implementation of the TA;

6.  Economics  editor  (4  person-months).  An  editor,  with  expertise  and  experience  in

notably those with an economics and developing country orientation. 
 
C.  National Consultants  
 
7.  Labor market specialists and education and skills specialists (25 persons-months). 
The consultants will have extensive and expert knowledge of the labor market or education and 
training sector in their selected country, and have demonstrated strong capacity in conducting 
quantitative and policy-oriented analysis of the education system and labor market policies and 
regulations.  Under  the  supervision  of  the  team  leader  and  supported  by  the  senior  labor 
economist and senior education specialist, each national expert will do the following: 
(i)  understand and internalize the diagnostic framework developed under the TA;  
(ii)  apply the framework in analyzing the constraints to the generation of greater 
human capital and decent employment in the country, engage in discussions with 
key stakeholders as part of the analysis, and prepare relevant and realistic policy 
recommendations; 
(iii)  prepare a draft country assessment in accordance with the analysis conducted 
under (ii) above and incorporate comments provided into a subsequent final 
version; 
(iv)  participate  in  consultations  and  assist  in  the  dissemination  of  the  research 
findings to relevant stakeholders, as needed; and 
(v)  perform  other  tasks  that  may  be  required  to  ensure  successful  and  timely 
completion of the country report. 
 
8.  Legal experts (3 person-months). Short-term legal experts may, in each country, be 
required if the international employment or labor market specialists (paras. 2–3) do not have the 
expertise in this regard. The experts will have knowledge of labor market laws and regulations, 
and will analyze the extent to which laws affect hiring and employment. 
 
9.  Research assistant (as needed). The consultant will have a degree in economics and 
will do the following:  
(i)  provide research and assistance; 
(ii)  compile and maintain a database of all data collected and used in the preparation 
of the study; 
(iii)  assist  in  organizing  and  facilitating  meetings,  consultations  and  workshops, 
including  logistical  requirements,  documentation,  secretariat  services, 
dissemination of information, and material and related support; 
(iv)  provide inputs and assist in the preparation and finalization of reports and other 
documents as required;

(vi)  perform other tasks relevant to the TA. 
 
10.  Graphics and layout specialist (6 person-months). The graphics and layout specialist 
will have expertise in the graphics and layout and will assist in the production of the TA’s 
publications. Activities will include the layout of text, tables, and charts; the conversion of files 
into the required formats for publication; and more generally, working with the project’s team 
leader  and  senior  specialists.  The  specialist  will  also  be  asked  to  provide  options  and 
suggestions  for  ensuring  that  publications  are  graphically  appealing,  engaging,  and  highly 
readable.
